name: skidding, skidder | skidding, skidder | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/11027/documentation

The inventory refers to 1 productive machine hour (PMS) - referring to the operational time of the machine including breaks up to 15 minutes - of a large skidder with an engine power of 130 kW and a total weight of 12,000 kg.;A skidder is any type of heavy vehicle used in a logging operation for pulling cut trees out of a forest in a process called "skidding", in which the logs are transported from the cutting site to a landing. Here they are loaded onto trucks  and sent to the mill. Modern forms of skidders can pull trees with a cable/winch, or a grapple or a clam-bunk. See infrastructure dataset for more details.;;;Assumed fuel consumption: 13 l/PMH; total service life: 12,000 PMH, average daily transport distance of machinery: 25 km.;Productivity depends on the specific circumstances of the harvesting operation and is specified in the respective datasets.;;The following sources have been consulted for the elaboration and plausibilisation of the dataset:;    Anonymous (2004): DIRECTIVE 2004/26/EC OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 21 April 2004 amending Directive 97/68/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to measures against the emission of gaseous and particulate pollutants from internal combustion engines to be installed in non-road mobile machinery. Official Journal of the European Union: 30.4.2004;    Athanassiadis, D., G. Lidestav and I. Wästerlund (1999): Fuel, hydraulic oil and lubricant consumption in Swedish mechanized harvesting operations, 1996. Journal of Forest Engineering, 10(1): 59-66.;    Klvac, R. and A. Skoupy (2009): Characteristic fuel consumption and exhaust emissions in fully mechanized logging operations. Journal of Forest Research, 14(6): 328-334: referring to Freitas 2004.;    Klvac, R., S. Ward, P. M. O. Owende and J. Lyons (2003): Energy audit of wood harvesting systems. Scandinavian Journal of Forest Research, 18(2): 176-183.;    Knechtle, N. (1997): Materialprofile von Holzerntesystemen - Analyse ausgewählter Beispiele als Grundlage für ein forsttechnisches Ökoinventar. Diplomarbeit am Departement für Wald- und Holzforschung. ETH Zürich, Zürich.;     Markewitz, D. (2006): Fossil fuel carbon emissions from silviculture: Impacts on net carbon sequestration in forests. Forest Ecology and Management, 263: 153-161.;    Riezinger, A. (2008): Die Ermittlung der ökologischen Effizienz der Bereitstellungskette von Waldhackgut anhand ausgewählter Fallstudien; Diplomarbeit. Universität der Bodenkultur (BOKU), Wien: referring to Schweinle and Thoroe 2001 (for consumption of hydraulic oil) and Pausch 2002 (for consumption of diesel fuel);    Spielmann, M., L. Barreto, V. Erni, F. Frutig and O. Thees (2007): Life cycle assessment of energy wood chip supply chains; a case study of near future supply of forest wood chips in Switzerland (unpublished). Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), Swiss Federal Institute for Forest, Snow and Landscape Research (WSL), Villigen, Birmensdorf.;    Wittkopf, S., U. Hömer and S. Feller (2003): Bereitstellungsverfahren für Waldhackschnitzel - Leistungen, Kosten, Rahmenbedingungen. Bayer. Landesanstalt für Wald und Forstwirtschaft, Freising.

Service beginning with the transport of the machinery to the logging site.

Includes the input of machinery infrastructure, the input of diesel fuel, lubricants/greases as well as their disposal, and the emissions into air from diesel consumption. Wood is not included in the dataset.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/022:Logging/0220:Logging

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Emission profile according to European legislation
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Material and fuel input from literature sources (see general comments field); air-borne emissions taken from existing dataset on diesel consumption in building machines or - where emission levels beyond applicable European legislation - estimated with emissions model based on emission limits established in European Directive 2004/ 26/EC for non-road mobile machinery types EURO IIIa and IIIb (according to Lambrecht et al 2004 and e.g. applied in Spielmann et al. 2007).

exchanges.description: Amount was scaled to 1.

flow.name: Ammonia
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
emission model calculating hourly specific emissions as "engine power x load factor x base emission factor" as proposed by Lambrecht et al. (2004) and applied in Spielmann et al. (2007); values for base emission factors for particles for mobile machine classes EURO IIIa and EUROIIIb are taken from European Directive 2004/ 26/EC. The proportional distribution accross particle classes is made based on the ecoinvent v3 dataset "Diesel, burned in building machine/GLO".
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, < 2.5 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
emission model calculating hourly specific emissions as "engine power x load factor x base emission factor" as proposed by Lambrecht et al. (2004) and applied in Spielmann et al. (2007);  values for base emission factors for VOC for mobile machinery classes EURO IIIa and EURO IIIb are taken from European Directive 2004/ 26/EC, of which 2.4% are assumed to be methane.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Selenium IV
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
emission model calculating hourly specific emissions as "engine power x load factor x base emission factor" as proposed by Lambrecht et al. (2004) and applied in Spielmann et al. (2007);  values for base emission factors for NOx for mobile machine class EUROIIIb are taken from the European Directive 2004/ 26/EC; for mobile machine class EURO IIIa values for base emission factors for NOx are calculated based on an assumed reduction of VOC emissions as compared to "Tier 2" limit for VOC of 1.0 g/kWh (following Spielmann et al. 2007).
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
